caption:
M. trichosporium OB3b was cultivated in mineral salts media containing 
cupric sulfate. As shown in Fig. 1, the growth rate of M. trichosporium OB3b 
and the maximum cell density decreased with increasing Cu concentration, 
up to 20 ~M. The maximum specific growth rate was 1.59 x 10-3/min, and 
the maximum cell density was 0.235 mg dry cell/mL at 1.25 ~d of Cu con- 
centration. M. trichosporium OB3b grew nicely at 1.25 ~,/of Cu concentra- 
tion, and grew slowly at 20 ~M of Cu concentration.

Fig. 1. Effect of Cu concentration on the growth of M. trichosporium OB3b. M. tri- 
chosporium OB3b was grown in the mineral salts medium at 30~ under methane-air 
(1:4 v/v%). The flask, were agitated on a rotary shaker table maintained at 120 rpm. 
Cu concentration in the medium: [], 0.21 ~tM; 9 1.25 ~tM; A, 20 ~tM.

Fig. 2. Factors affecting methanol accumulation. (A) the effect of cell density; 
(B) the effect of temperature; (C) the effect of sodium formate concentration.

Fig. 3. Effect of cyclopropanol concentration on pMMO activity and MDH activity. 
The pMMO activity (o) was measured by propene epoxidation assay. The reaction 
mixture contains cell suspension (34.6 mg dry cell/mL), propylene (112 ~tmol), 
sodium formate (14.3 mM), and various concentrations of cyclopropanol in phos- 
phate buffer (12.9 mM), pH 7.0. The MDH activity (9 was measured by methanol oxi- 
dation assay. The reaction mixture contains cell suspension (34.6 mg dry cell/mL), 
methanol (18 ~tmol), and various concentrations of cyclopropanol in phosphate buffer 
(22 mM), pH 7.0. The reaction was carried out at 30~ The total volume of reaction 
mixture was 3.5 mL.

Fig. 4 Effect of cyclopropanol concentration on methanol accumulation. The reac- 
tion of mixture contains cell suspension (1.39 g dry cell/mL), methane (112 ~tmol), oxy- 
gen (103 ~tmol), and sodium formate (14.3 raM) in phosphate buffer (58.6 mM), pH 7.0. 
The reaction was carried out at 30~

Fig. 5. Time-course of methanol produced by M. trichosporium OB3b. The methanol 
synthesis was carried out with conventional conditions (9 with optimum conditions 
(A). The reaction conditions were described in Table 2.
